intro: Corymbium glabrum var. rogersii, commonly known as the Rogers' corymbium, is a flowering plant native to specific regions of North America. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes many other flowering plants with small, cruciform flowers. The plant is characterized by its glabrous (smooth) surfaces and clustered inflorescences that produce small, white or pale yellow flowers. It typically grows in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in open habitats such as meadows and woodland edges. Due to its limited distribution and specific ecological requirements, it is considered a rare and sometimes endangered species.
